lexicon_requests.reason: Unique superscription in Psalter - need semantic distinction from mizmor and theological significance
Physical elevation metaphor for praise - need range of meaning and cultic usage
Epistemological limit concept - rare term for unfathomable/unsearchable
Intensive praise participle - morphology and theological intensity
Category of divine acts distinct from works - need technical theological range
Third category of divine acts - wondrous deeds semantic field
Liquid metaphor for praise - gush/bubble forth unusual usage
Anthropomorphic patience idiom - literal nose-length metaphor
Faithful ones within universal scope - covenant relationship terminology
Royal theology central to psalm - kingship vs kingdom distinction
Eternal ages concept in climactic verse - temporal theology
Temporal tension verb - hope/wait with expectant looking
Condition for divine nearness - truth/faithfulness as ethical requirement

concordance_requests.purpose: Track rare tehillah superscription vs. common mizmor usage
Eternal kingdom formula - possible Ugaritic parallels
Holy name theology in praise contexts

figurative_requests.reason: Gushing forth liquid metaphor for praise expression - vivid and unusual | Vehicle: gushing | Related terms: gush, bubble, pour, pours, pouring, flow, flows, flowing, spring, springs
Nostril-length as patience metaphor - specific anthropomorphic idiom | Vehicle: nostril | Related terms: nostrils, nose, breathing, breath
Falling and bending as vulnerability metaphor - physical states as spiritual conditions | Vehicle: falling | Related terms: fall, falls, fallen, stumble, stumbles, stumbling
Straightening/raising up imagery for divine help - physical restoration metaphor | Vehicle: straightening | Related terms: straighten, raise, raises, raising, lift, lifts, lifting, upright
Eyes looking up in expectation - visual dependency metaphor | Vehicle: expectation | Related terms: expect, expects, expecting, hope, hopes, hoping, wait, waits, waiting
Open hand gesture for provision - simple gesture with cosmic implications | Vehicle: opening | Related terms: open, opens, opened, extend, extends, extending

commentary_requests.reason: Universal mercy scope vs. selective judgment (v20) - how do commentators resolve this theological tension?
LXX plus line about faithfulness - early interpretive tradition and why it was added
Destruction of wicked within universal praise context - limits to divine mercy
All flesh scope - does this include all living creatures or only humans in traditional interpretation?

ugaritic_parallels.analysis: This shared formula for celebrating divine kingship demonstrates a common liturgical and royal vocab...

macro_questions: How does the possible missing nun verse affect interpretation of the psalm's acrostic structure and theological completeness?
What is the significance of the Ugaritic parallel in v. 13 for understanding Israelite royal theology and divine kingship?
How does the frequent use of כל (all/every) function rhetorically to build the psalm's universalist vision?
What specific Hebrew terminology is used for divine 'works' (מַעֲשֶׂיךָ) versus 'mighty acts' (גְּבוּרֹתֶיךָ) and how do these categories function theologically?
How does the generational language (דּ֣וֹר לְ֭דוֹר) relate to covenant theology and the transmission of faith?
What is the relationship between divine transcendence (vv. 3, 11-13) and immanent care (vv. 14-20) in the psalm's theological structure?
How does the movement from 'I will bless' to 'all creatures shall bless' function as a model for expanding worship participation?
What is the significance of the contrast between divine care for the righteous and destruction of the wicked in v. 20?
How does the psalm's use of traditional divine epithets (v. 8) connect to broader biblical covenantal language?
What role does creation theology play in the psalm's vision of universal praise?
micro_questions: Why does the psalm use the unique superscription 'תְּהִלָּה' instead of the common 'מִזְמוֹר'?
What accounts for the apparent missing nun verse in the acrostic structure - scribal error or theological intention?
How does the triple accumulation 'הֲדַר כְּבוֹד הוֹדֶךָ' function - semantic distinction or poetic intensification?
Why does the LXX add an extra line about God's faithfulness after v13?
How do we reconcile universal divine mercy (v9) with the destruction of the wicked (v20)?
What distinguishes 'works' (מַעֲשֶׂיךָ) from 'mighty acts' (גְּבוּרֹתֶיךָ) from 'wondrous acts' (נִפְלְאֹתֶיךָ)?
Does 'all flesh' (כׇּל־בָּשָׂר) in v21 include all living creatures or only humans?
Why combine liquid metaphor (יַבִּיעוּ - gush forth) with musical imagery (יְרַנֵּנוּ - sing) in v7?
What does 'calling in truth' (בֶאֱמֶת) mean as a condition for divine nearness?
